p: Figure 3 shows the immobility time of the examined mice in the forced swimming test: the latency of control group mice was 109.50 ± 7.13 s. The immobility time of the mice treated with trazodone hydrochloride, a prescription antidepressant, was significantly shorter (39.75 ± 3.69 s) than that of control mice at the dose of 100 mg/kg. The leaf oil also induced the considerable reduction in immobility time compared with the vehicle control, with a statistical difference ( p < 0.05); the immobility time of the treated mice was 64.50 ± 4.81 s at the dose of 200 mg/kg. The antidepressant behavior of mice can be markedly improved by the oral administration of the C. osmophloeum ct. linalool leaf oil.
